content.text: A unit may be stated with a prefix that represents a power-of-ten multiple or submultiple
Complete Table 1.1 to show the name and symbol of each prefix and the corresponding power-of-ten multiple or submultiple
In the following list, underline all the units that are SI base units
ampere coulomb metre newton
The quantities listed in Table 1.2 have values that are used to calculate \(\rho\) as \(4.1 \times 10^{- 7} \Omega \text{m}\)
For this value of \(\rho\), calculate:
the percentage uncertainty
percentage uncertainty = .........%
the absolute uncertainty
absolute uncertainty = .........\(\Omega \text{m}\)
The potential difference \(V\) between the two ends of a uniform metal wire is given by
where \(d\) is the diameter of the wire,
\(I\) is the current in the wire,
\(L\) is the length of the wire,
and
\(\rho\) is the resistivity of the metal
For a particular wire, the percentage uncertainties in the values of some of the above quantities are listed in Table 1.2
Calculate the magnitude of the electric field strength
electric field strength = .........\(NC^{-1}\)
Determine the magnitude and the sign of the charge on the oil drop
magnitude of charge = .........C
sign of charge
Compare the new pattern of the electric field lines between the plates with the original pattern
Determine the magnitude of the resultant force acting on the oil drop
resultant force = .........N
Show that the magnitude of the acceleration of the oil drop is \(20 \text{m s}^{-2}\)
Assume that the radius of the oil drop is negligible
Use the information in **(b)**(iii) to calculate the time taken for the oil drop to move to the bottom metal plate from its initial position mid-way between the plates

The electric potentials of the plates are instantaneously reversed so that the top plate is at a potential of 0V and the bottom plate is at a potential of +1340V. This change causes the oil drop to start moving downwards
The oil drop in **(b)** starts to move at time \(t = 0\). The distance of the oil drop from the bottom plate is \(x\)

On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of distance \(x\) for the movement of the drop from its initial position until it hits the surface of the bottom plate. Numerical values of \(t\) are not required

A charged oil drop is in a vacuum between two horizontal metal plates. A uniform electric field is produced between the plates by applying a potential difference of \(1340\mathrm{V}\) across them, as shown in Fig. 2.1
The separation of the plates is \(1.4 \times 10^{-2} \text{m}\)
The oil drop of weight \(4.6 \times 10^{-14} \text{N}\) remains stationary at a point mid-way between the plates
Define power
state the change in the kinetic energy
change in kinetic energy = .........J
calculate the work done against the total resistive force
work done = .........J
A car of mass \(1700\mathrm{kg}\) moves in a straight line along a slope that is at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal, as shown in Fig. 3.1
The car moves at constant velocity for a distance of \(25\mathrm{m}\) from point A to point B
Air resistance and friction provide a total resistive force of \(440\mathrm{N}\) that opposes the motion of the car
For the movement of the car from A to B:
the increase in vertical height \(h\) of the car for its movement from A to B
angle \(\theta\)
The movement of the car in **(b)** from A to B causes its gravitational potential energy to increase by \(4.8 \times 10^{4} \text{ J}\)
Calculate:
The engine of the car in **(b)** produces an output power of \(1.7 \times 10^{4} \text{W}\) to move the car along the slope
Calculate the time taken for the car to move from A to B
from time \(t = 0\) to time \(t = 2.0 \text{s}\)
from time \(t = 4.0 \text{s}\) to time \(t = 6.0 \text{s}\)
Describe qualitatively the variation, if any, in the frequency of the sound heard, by the child, that was emitted from the car horn:
Determine the frequency, to three significant figures, of the sound heard, by the child, that was emitted from the car horn at time \(t = 3.0 \text{s}\)
frequency = .........Hz
Determine the time taken for the sound emitted at time \(t = 4.0 \text{s}\) to travel to the child
time taken = .........s

A child sits on the ground next to a remote-controlled toy car. At time \(t = 0\), the car begins to move in a straight line directly away from the child. The variation with time \(t\) of the velocity of the car along this line is shown in Fig. 4.1
The car's horn continually emits sound of frequency \(925\mathrm{Hz}\) between time \(t = 0\) and time \(t = 6.0\mathrm{s}\). The speed of the sound in the air is \(338\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\)
Describe a simple way that a student, without requiring any additional equipment, can detect when a stationary wave is formed in the air column as the tube is being raised
Determine the height of the top end of the tube above the surface of the water when a stationary wave is first produced in the tube. Assume that an antinode is formed level with the top of the tube
height = .........m
Determine the distance moved by the tube between the positions at which the first and second stationary waves are formed
distance = .........m
A tube is initially fully submerged in water. The axis of the tube is kept vertical as the tube is slowly raised out of the water, as shown in Fig. 5.1

A loudspeaker producing sound of frequency \(530\mathrm{Hz}\) is positioned at the open top end of the tube as it is raised. The water surface inside the tube is always level with the water surface outside the tube. The speed of the sound in the air column in the tube is \(340\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\)
Calculate the charge passing through the cell in a time of 7.5 minutes
charge = .........C
Calculate the percentage efficiency with which the cell supplies power to wire X
efficiency = .........%
the number density \(n\) of the free electrons
the average drift speed of the free electrons
There are \(3.2 \times 10^{22}\) free (conduction) electrons contained in the volume of wire X
For wire X, calculate:
A wire Y has the same cross-sectional area as wire X and is made of the same metal. Wire Y is longer than wire X
Wire X in the circuit is now replaced by wire Y. Assume that wire Y has the same temperature as wire X
State and explain whether the average drift speed of the free electrons in wire Y is greater than, the same as, or less than that in wire X
A cell of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(0.48 \text{V}\) is connected to a metal wire X, as shown in Fig. 6.1
The cell has internal resistance. The current in the cell is \(0.80 \text{A}\)
Wire X has length \(3.0 \text{m}\), cross-sectional area \(1.3 \times 10^{-7} \text{m}^2\) and resistance \(0.40 \Omega\)
Use the principle of conservation of momentum to explain why the initial velocities of nucleus Q and the \(\alpha\) -particle must be in opposite directions
Determine the initial speed \(\nu\) of nucleus Q
Calculate the initial kinetic energy, in MeV, of the \(\alpha\) -particle
kinetic energy = .........MeV
On Fig. 7.2, draw a cross to represent:
1. nucleus R (label this cross R)
2. nucleus S (label this cross S)
State the name of the other lepton, in addition to the \(\beta^{- }\) particle, that is emitted during the decay of nucleus R
A graph of number of neutrons \(N\) against proton number \(Z\) is shown in Fig. 7.2
The graph shows a cross that represents nucleus P
A nucleus R has a nucleon number of 242 and is an isotope of nucleus P
Nucleus R decays by emitting a \(\beta^{- }\) particle to form a different nucleus S
A stationary nucleus P of mass \(243 \mathrm{u}\) decays by emitting an \(\alpha\) -particle of mass \(4 \mathrm{u}\) to form a different nucleus Q, as illustrated in Fig. 7.1
BEFORE DECAY
AFTER DECAY
The initial speed of the \(\alpha\) -particle is \(1.6 \times 10^{7} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\)
